user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of get_nonce_timestamp:
```c
static bool
get_nonce_timestamp (const char *const nonce,
                     size_t noncelen,
                     uint64_t *const ptimestamp)
{
  if (0 == noncelen)
    noncelen = strlen (nonce);

  if (true
#ifdef MHD_MD5_SUPPORT
      && (NONCE_STD_LEN (MD5_DIGEST_SIZE) != noncelen)
#endif /* MHD_MD5_SUPPORT */
#if defined(MHD_SHA256_SUPPORT) || defined(MHD_SHA512_256_SUPPORT)
      && (NONCE_STD_LEN (SHA256_SHA512_256_DIGEST_SIZE) != noncelen)
#endif /* MHD_SHA256_SUPPORT */
      )
    return false;

  if (TIMESTAMP_CHARS_LEN !=
      MHD_strx_to_uint64_n_ (nonce + noncelen - TIMESTAMP_CHARS_LEN,
                             TIMESTAMP_CHARS_LEN,
                             ptimestamp))
    return false;
  return true;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Other code fragments do not need investigation for Rule 8.13: the nonce parameter is declared as const char *const (the pointed-to type is already const-qualified), the use of strlen(nonce) and the pointer arithmetic (nonce + noncelen - TIMESTAMP_CHARS_LEN) only read from the const-qualified nonce, and there are no other pointer declarations in this function. Therefore the only places where a pointer points to a non-const-qualified type that could be relevant to Rule 8.13 are the ptimestamp parameter and its use when passed to MHD_strx_to_uint64_n_.
